instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> a no backlight
threads.message: On <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> in pin 3 and 4 i have the same voltage so <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> doesn't open i checked the voltage divider the <RESISTOR>R7788</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7789</RESISTOR> are good but anyway i replace them and still im getting same voltage on 3 and 4 looks like the divider is not lowering the voltage. Any ides ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> a no backlight
threads.message: <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> is missing I bet. Do you even have an image? Is <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> a no backlight
threads.message: Yes <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> is missing its hard to see if there is an image when i plug usb dongle is not lighting up i have <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> and the <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is 3.4V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> a no backlight
threads.message: Uhm, you mean the board is just brain dead? USB mouse not lighting up?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> a no backlight
threads.message: So this board was water damage around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> so i replaced the chip and there was damaged via's that i jumped wires and the computer turned on i boot it to OS but i had so much flux on the board so i wash it in the ultrasonic cleaner again and it didn't gave me backlight after or image not sure. I do proper ultrasonic cleaning if you want to ask that with CREST and proper Branson solution and dry the board next go to alchohol and in oven for 10 min on 200 degrees celsius.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> a no backlight
threads.message: Look like brain dead but i'm not sure

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> a no backlight
threads.message:
200C for drying a board?? That will melt all your repairs with normal solder! 120C is more than enough.
No idea what happened now, inspect for corrosion or damaged components.

Plug in a USB mouse and see if it lights up, if not it is brain dead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> a no backlight
threads.message: sorry it Fahrenheit lol. Yes no light on USB

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> a no backlight
threads.message: Well, there must be corrosion somewhere else too. The usual spots, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>/resistors, clock chip, under SMC
